issue.title: Local/AWS docker simulation does not always start

content.raw: Martin, in your velocity controller/issuer is there any sort of logic that will time-out if your autonomy stack does not see your robot respond to velocity commands it is issuing \(this is the case for move-base\).  Would your velocity controller continue sending commands throughout the entire simulation duration irregardless of whether or not the robot had responded to commands in the past?  It seems the velocity controller startup is delayed as you have pointed out and that could be an issue.  To clarify, robot B moved but robot A did not move?
content.html: Martin, in your velocity controller/issuer is there any sort of logic that will time-out if your autonomy stack does not see your robot respond to velocity commands it is issuing (this is the case for move-base). Would your velocity controller continue sending commands throughout the entire simulation duration irregardless of whether or not the robot had responded to commands in the past? It seems the velocity controller startup is delayed as you have pointed out and that could be an issue. To clarify, robot B moved but robot A did not move?
